awd_titl_txt: The Nanotechnology Applications and Career Knowledge (NACK) Support Center
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanotechnology is constantly impacting society through the field of nanoelectronics and large numbers of nanotechnology-based products in other fields, such as health care, automotive and transportation, safety and security, and home and leisure. The existing Nanotechnology Applications and Career Knowledge (NACK) Network will transition to the NACK Support Center with the objective of continuing to support U.S. nanotechnology workforce education. The NACK Support Center will employ its community and technical college (CC)-industry-research university (RU) partnerships to carry out: 1) resource sharing among CCs as well as among CCs and RUs; 2) dissemination of learning materials that deliver a core set of industry-recommended nanotechnology skills; 3) live-streaming of professional development webinars; and 4) creation of more effective approaches for disseminating resources and expanding dissemination methodologies through a NACK website with added services and enhanced functionality.

NACK will carry out its work by: continuing to support and develop new nodes in the Remotely Accessible Instruments for Nanotechnology (RAIN) Network; adding new online-accessible characterization and processing tools; developing ways to increase awareness and usage of RAIN resources; and collecting data and statistics to evaluate RAIN's impact on nanotechnology education. Through a partnership with the industry standards organization ASTM International, NACK educational materials from its six core-skills courses will be institutionalized into industry standards. This partnership will allow students and working technicians to earn up to 6 stackable ASTM certificates with worldwide industry recognition via ASTM-administered tests based on these core courses. By continually updating core-skills course material and adapting it to online delivery via videoed lectures and labs, and by growing on-line course and equipment accessibility, educational opportunities will become increasingly available to highly diverse secondary and post-secondary level populations. The NACK Support Center's planned outreach to veterans and underrepresented student groups will address a key need to recruit these groups for advanced STEM education, and broaden nanotechnology awareness in general. Business outreach and the stackable certificate program will promote technician careers and visibility among a broad range of industries.

por.por_cntn:
The Nanotechnology Applications and Career Knowledge (NACK) Support Center was established to assist in the continued development of a robust nationwide infrastructure for nanotechnology workforce development.  The main NACK Support Center sought out to support and propagate resource sharing and nano-education partnerships, facilitate the collaboration between CCs and nearby universities, develop, update, and enhance the quality of educational material resources, recruit technical experts to conduct live-streamed webinars, host educator?s workshops, support and develop the remotely accessible instruments for nanotechnology (RAIN) network, develop and administer nanotechnology stackable workforce certificates, and to reach out to industry and work with underrepresented student groups such as veterans. 

A supplemental to the NACK support center was established with the major goal being to develop and pilot a ?Nanotechnology Certificate Program (NCP)? for veterans based in the Virginia Beach area.  The major goals for this project were to pilot the NCP program by recruiting veterans for the course and providing them with hands-on training at Norfolk State University. 

The outcomes of the support center based on the goals of the original support center along with the more focused goals of the supplemental support center are outline below:

Support and propagate resource sharing: Since 2016 there have been 13,398 opens of the Nanowire newsletter.  The nanoHub has served 127,048 users since 2016.  In the last calendar year (March 2022 ? March 2023) the nanoHub served 33,695 users with nanotechnology educational resources.  There have been a total of 59,880 downloads of educational materials from the NACK websites from a total of 3,644 registered users.  In total, there have been over 300 CC?s/TC?s who have used CNEU resources (programs, courses, modules, webinars, professional development).

Facilitate the collaboration between CCs and nearby universities: Penn State University has partnered with close to a dozen Pennsylvania based CCs and developed a resource sharing model most effective for providing the hands-on training in the areas of nanotechnology and semiconductor manufacturing.  This model has been replicated by various institutions throughout the country.  In total there are now 18 nanotechnology workforce education partnerships formed across 16 states. 

Develop, Update, and Enhance the quality of Educational Material Resources: A total of 11 nanotechnology courses have been developed and regularly updated.

Webinars: There have been 64 NACK National Webinars with a total of 4,453 registrants.  There have been 20,050 views of these NACK Webinar recordings. 

Workshops: In 2022 there were 3 workshops with a total of 57 attendees.  During workshops, activities to bring nanotechnology-based experiments into the classroom were shared and discussed.  In total there have been 1,900 educators and industry personnel who have completed NACK workshops with 313 of those being NACK?s live-streamed workshops beginning in 2018.

Support and develop the RAIN network: In 2022 there were a total of 51 remote access sessions reaching 655 students.  The RAIN network continues to develop and evolve.  Rio Salado Community College and Heritage University were both recently added to the RAIN network.  Rio Salado has brought the first optical profiler onto the network, adding to the diversity of instrumentation available.  There have been a total of 631 RAIN sessions reaching 11,808 students. 

Develop and administer nanotechnology stackable workforce certificates: Since 2016 there have been 6 International Standards for Nanotechnology Workforce Education developed under NACK leadership through ASTM International.  Based on these standards 3 international accreditation certificates have been developed.  A total of 43 ASTM certificates have been awarded to date.

Reach out to Industry:  A variety of industry partners have gotten involved with the ultimate hope of recruiting credentialed students following their graduation.  Industry involvement ranges from providing live-streamed presentations to hosting facility tours.  Industry partners now include Tokyo Electron, TSMC, Micron, GlobalFoundries, Qorvo, WesterwoodGlobal, NXP Semiconductor, Nanoscience Instruments, and more.  

Taking the NCP national:  Following the successful pilot of the NCP (8 students) the model was awarded to be taken nationally.  The NCP was expanded to 4 total locations throughout the country strategically selected based on proximity to a military base and a research university with a cleanroom available for the hands-on training.  These locations include Virginia Beach Virginia, Atlanta Georgia, Phoenix Arizona, and San Diego California.  The national program was piloted in Spring of 2023 and is projected to have more than 20 graduates in late April of 2023.  A large portion of these graduates plan to either enter industry or continue schooling following the NCP. 

The goals of the original support center have been accomplished.  The supplemental support center has successfully piloted the NCP program and developed the model which is now being used nationally to educate veterans in nanotechnology and semiconductor manufacturing. 


Last Modified: 04/11/2023
Modified by: Osama Awadelkarim

A supplemental to the NACK support center was established with the major goal being to develop and pilot a ?Nanotechnology Certificate Program (NCP)? for veterans based in the Virginia Beach area.  The major goals for this project were to pilot the NCP program by recruiting veterans for the course and providing them with hands-on training at Norfolk State University.

Facilitate the collaboration between CCs and nearby universities: Penn State University has partnered with close to a dozen Pennsylvania based CCs and developed a resource sharing model most effective for providing the hands-on training in the areas of nanotechnology and semiconductor manufacturing.  This model has been replicated by various institutions throughout the country.  In total there are now 18 nanotechnology workforce education partnerships formed across 16 states.

In total there have been 1,900 educators and industry personnel who have completed NACK workshops with 313 of those being NACK?s live-streamed workshops beginning in 2018.

Industry involvement ranges from providing live-streamed presentations to hosting facility tours.  Industry partners now include Tokyo Electron, TSMC, Micron, GlobalFoundries, Qorvo, WesterwoodGlobal, NXP Semiconductor, Nanoscience Instruments, and more.

The goals of the original support center have been accomplished.  The supplemental support center has successfully piloted the NCP program and developed the model which is now being used nationally to educate veterans in nanotechnology and semiconductor manufacturing.
